{{Use dmy dates|date=June 2011}} {{Use Australian English|date=June 2011}} {{Infobox Australian rules football match | year = 2004 | competition = AFL | match_type = Line in the sand match
Round 11, 2004
Hawthorn v Essendon | image = [[File:Before the bounce at the MCG.jpg|center|200px]] | home = {{AFL Haw}} | home_abbr = HAW | home_image = | away = {{AFL Ess}} | away_abbr = ESS | away_image = | home_qtr1 = 2.2 (14) | home_qtr2 = 5.3 (33) | home_qtr3 = 7.6 (48) | home_qtr4 = 12.8 (80) | away_qtr1 = 6.4 (40) | away_qtr2 = 10.5 (65) | away_qtr3 = 19.8 (122) | away_qtr4 = 24.10 (154) | home_score = 12.8 (80) | away_score = 24.10 (154) | date = 5 June 2004 | stadium = [[Melbourne Cricket Ground|MCG]] | attendance = 42,682 | umpire = | coin_toss = | kick_end = | network = [[Network Ten]] | commentators = }} The '''line in the sand match''' is the unofficial title given to the [[2004 AFL season#Round 11|round 11, 2004]] match between [[Australian Football League]] (AFL) clubs {{AFL Haw}} and {{AFL Ess}}, which was played at the [[Melbourne Cricket Ground]] on Saturday, 5 June 2004. A number of incidents in the third quarter led to some fights breaking out all over the ground, eventually turning into a five-minute melee involving all players on the ground.{{citation needed|date=June 2013}} Following the brawl, Essendon kicked fourteen goals to Hawthorn's six to record a 74-point win. Eighteen players faced charges at the [[AFL Tribunal]] from the match on 8 and 9 June 2004, with record suspensions and fines handed out. ==Background== Throughout the 1980s and early 1990s, Hawthorn experienced a golden era, making every Grand Final from 1983 to 1989 and again in 1991, and were victorious on five occasions. During this time, they came up against the Bombers on three occasions – [[1983 VFL Grand Final|1983]], [[1984 VFL Grand Final|1984]] and [[1985 VFL Grand Final|1985]]. The Hawks comfortably won in 1983 and the Bombers followed up with [[List of Australian Football League premiers#Back-to-back premierships|back-to-back]] wins in 1984 and 1985. Throughout this decade, both clubs were known to play hard, attacking brands of football resulting in lots of biffs, bumps and brawls. Essendon continued to intimidate opposition clubs in the 1990s and into the early years of the 21st century, resulting in more premiership success in 1993 and 2000, and a dominant era over Hawthorn. Essendon entered the match having won nine of the previous ten meetings between the two clubs, by an average margin of 39 points. They were also heavy favourites to win this match, having a 7–3 win–loss record for the season and were considered a top-four contender, while Hawthorn was bottom of the ladder with only two wins. ==During the match== ===Lead up to the brawl=== Hawthorn players were allegedly directed at half time, by club director [[Dermott Brereton]] who played for the Hawks during the 1980s and early 1990s, to "draw a line in the sand"{{cite news|first=Richard|last=Hinds|title=Heavier blows to come for Hawks, Bombers|date=7 June 2004|url=http://www.smh.com.au/articles/2004/06/06/1086460175315.html|publisher=The Sydney Morning Herald|location=Sydney}} and take a physical stand against the Bombers to make it clear that they would not take the intimidation any longer. Brereton denied the allegation but admitted to advising senior players "to stand up to any Essendon aggression".{{cite web|first=Chris|last=Lines|date=6 June 2004|title=AFL: I didn't order fight - Brereton|url=http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1P1-95261082.html|publisher=AAP Sports News (Australia)|accessdate=2009-08-22}} Within the first two minutes of the third quarter, [[Mark Williams (Australian footballer born 1983)|Mark Williams]] kicked Hawthorn's sixth goal of the match to cut Essendon's lead to 26 points.{{cite video|date=5 June 2004 |title=Saturday Afternoon Football: Hawthorn v Essendon |url=http://bigpondvideo.com/AFL/14937?Quarters=3 |publisher=[[Network 10]] |location=Melbourne |time=1:22 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111005011914/http://bigpondvideo.com/AFL/14937?Quarters=3 |archivedate= 5 October 2011 |df= }} Following the centre bounce, several players were on the ground vigorously attempting to gain possession of the ball and clear it for their team. [[Mark Johnson (footballer)|Mark Johnson]] of Essendon attempted to join in at a stoppage but was quickly removed by a number of Hawthorn players. This led to some wrestling and jumper punches amongst the players, with approximately 16 players in the centre square at the time. [[Channel Ten (Australia)|Channel Ten]] commentators said that the spirit was "bubbling over a little". A free kick was awarded to Hawthorn and the ball was quickly kicked forward. The Hawks were unable to take a mark inside their forward 50 and the ball fell into [[Mark Bolton]]'s hands who was able to clear for the Bombers. He kicked the ball along the southern side of the ground with the aim of reaching [[Jason Winderlich]] who, while attempting to mark close to the ground, copped a very hard knock from Hawthorn's [[Chance Bateman]], possibly a knee or hip connecting with his head. A free kick was awarded to Winderlich who was forced from the ground under the [[blood rule]].{{cite video|date=5 June 2004 |title=Saturday Afternoon Football: Hawthorn v Essendon |url=http://bigpondvideo.com/AFL/14937?Quarters=3 |publisher=[[Network 10]] |location=Melbourne |time=2:50 - 3:50 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111005011914/http://bigpondvideo.com/AFL/14937?Quarters=3 |archivedate= 5 October 2011 |df= }} ===The brawl=== A number of brawls broke out on the Great Southern Stand side of the centre square with many players getting involved. Players tackled each other to the ground, threw fist and jumper punches and wrestled with each other with Hawthorn's [[Richie Vandenberg]] and [[Lance Picioane]] particularly active and Essendon's [[Adam McPhee]], Mark Johnson and [[Justin Murphy (Australian rules footballer)|Justin Murphy]] were keen to respond. As Winderlich continued off the ground in the arms of trainers he was struck by [[Campbell Brown (footballer)|Campbell Brown]] of Hawthorn, an act which was described by Essendon forward [[Matthew Lloyd]] after the match as "one of the most disgusting things I've seen on a football field". Channel Ten commentators described it as "the 1980s revisited", "unbelievable" and stated "we haven't seen these sort of scenes for a long time in AFL football". Trainers, runners and some senior players were seen restraining and dragging their club's players away from opposition players, while McPhee had to be restrained and given marching orders from Bruce Connor, Essendon's head physiotherapist, to receive attention to a bloodied eye.{{cite video|date=5 June 2004 |title=Saturday Afternoon Football: Hawthorn v Essendon |url=http://bigpondvideo.com/AFL/14937?Quarters=3 |publisher=[[Network 10]] |location=Melbourne |time=5:33 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111005011914/http://bigpondvideo.com/AFL/14937?Quarters=3 |archivedate= 5 October 2011 |df= }} ===After the brawl=== A few follow-up scuffles occurred but Essendon regained composure and hit back hard on the scoreboard, kicking nine of the next ten goals to extend the three-quarter time lead to 74 points. A 10-goal final quarter, five to each team, left the margin as it was at three-quarter time, with the Bombers recording a 74-point win. ==Tribunal== The fallout from the match was significant, with a record 18 players reported on a record 26 charges. Some players were reported by umpires on the field,{{cite web |title=Round 11, 2004 Match Report |date=5 June 2004 |url=http://www.essendonfc.com.au/matches/past_report.asp?yr=2004&round_no=11 |publisher=Essendon Football Club |location=Melbourne |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120308134201/http://www.essendonfc.com.au/matches/past_report.asp?yr=2004&round_no=11 |archivedate= 8 March 2012 |df= }} while the rest were cited on video evidence by Video Reports Officer Ian Robinson{{cite web |title=Murphy and Beaumont cited |date=6 June 2004 |url=http://www.essendonfc.com.au/news/news.asp?nid=3570 |publisher=Essendon Football Club |location=Melbourne |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20050723093331/http://essendonfc.com.au/news/news.asp?nid=3570 |archivedate=23 July 2005 |df= }} and after an investigation conducted by the AFL's Investigations Officer Rick Lewis.{{cite web |title=Nine Bombers on melee charges |date=8 June 2004 |url=http://www.essendonfc.com.au/news/news.asp?nid=3578 |publisher=Essendon Football Club |location=Melbourne |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20050723025352/http://essendonfc.com.au/news/news.asp?nid=3578 |archivedate=23 July 2005 |df= }} ===Hawthorn=== {| class="wikitable" |- style="background:#efefef;" ! style="width:150pt;"| Player ! style="width:800pt;"| Charge |- |rowspan=2|[[John Barker (Australian footballer)|John Barker]] |Striking Adam McPhee, Essendon, in the third quarter. |- |Engaging in a melee during the third quarter. |- |rowspan=3|[[Simon Beaumont]] |Striking Justin Murphy during the third quarter. (Video evidence) |- |Misconduct in that on two occasions he thrust his head towards the face of Justin Murphy, Essendon, during the third quarter. |- |Engaging in a melee during the third quarter. |- |rowspan=3|[[Campbell Brown (footballer)|Campbell Brown]] |Wrestling with Dean Rioli, Essendon, during the third quarter. |- |Striking Jason Winderlich, Essendon, in the third quarter. |- |Engaging in a melee during the third quarter. |- |rowspan=3|[[Richie Vandenberg|Richard Vandenberg]] |Striking Adam McPhee, Essendon, during the third quarter. |- |Misconduct in that he made unnecessary and unreasonable contact with his leg to Adam McPhee, Essendon, during the third quarter. |- |Engaging in a melee during the third quarter. |- |rowspan=2|[[Lance Picioane]] |Striking Adam McPhee, Essendon, during the third quarter. |- |Engaging in a melee during the third quarter. |- |[[Chance Bateman]] |rowspan=4|Engaging in a melee during the third quarter. |- |[[Peter Everitt]] |- |[[Nick Holland]] |- |[[Mark Williams (Australian footballer born 1983)|Mark Williams]] |} ===Essendon=== {| class="wikitable" |- style="background:#efefef;" ! style="width:150pt;"| Player ! style="width:625pt;"| Charge |- |rowspan=2|[[Justin Murphy (Australian rules footballer)|Justin Murphy]] |Alleged misconduct in that he headbutted Simon Beaumont during the third quarter. (Video evidence) |- |Engaging in a melee during the third quarter. |- |[[Jason Johnson (Australian rules footballer)|Jason Johnson]] |rowspan=8|Engaging in a melee during the third quarter. |- |[[Mark Johnson (footballer)|Mark Johnson]] |- |[[Adam McPhee]] |- |[[Mark McVeigh]] |- |[[Damien Peverill]] |- |[[Dean Rioli]] |- |[[Dean Solomon]] |- |[[Andrew Welsh (footballer)|Andrew Welsh]] |} ==Tribunal outcomes== The Tribunal decisions were severe with five players suspended for a combined total of 16 matches{{cite web |title=Murphy out, Hawks pay heavy price |date=9 June 2004 |url=http://www.essendonfc.com.au/news/news.asp?nid=3583 |publisher=Essendon Football Club |location=Melbourne }} and players involved in the melee fined a combined total of $70,700,{{cite web |title=A fine day for the AFL |date=9 June 2004 |url=http://www.essendonfc.com.au/news/news.asp?nid=3584 |publisher=Essendon Football Club |location=Melbourne }} the most from a single match in VFL/AFL history, and described by Tribunal Chairman Brian Collis, QC, as bringing "football into disrepute".{{cite news|title=Hawks lose both players and respect|date=11 June 2004|url=http://www.theage.com.au/articles/2004/06/10/1086749836838.html|publisher=The Age|location=Melbourne|accessdate=2009-08-22}} ===Hawthorn=== Richard Vandenberg, Lance Picioane, Campbell Brown and Simon Beaumont were suspended for a combined total of 15 matches and melee fines totalled $36,700: {| class="wikitable" |- style="background:#efefef;" ! style="width:150pt;"| Player ! style="width:250pt;"| Charge ! style="width:200pt;"| Outcome |- |rowspan=3|Richard Vandenberg || Striking Adam McPhee || Suspended for 3 matches |- | Kneeing Adam McPhee || Suspended for 3 matches |- | Melee|| Fined $4,000 |- |rowspan=2|Lance Picioane || Striking Adam McPhee || Suspended for 4 matches |- |Melee || Fined $4,000 |- |rowspan=3|Campbell Brown || Striking Jason Winderlich || Suspended for 4 matches |- |Melee || Fined $4,000 |- |Wrestling with Dean Rioli || Fined $1,200 |- |rowspan=2|John Barker || Striking Adam McPhee || Cleared |- |Melee || Fined $4,500 |- |rowspan=3|Simon Beaumont || Striking Justin Murphy || Cleared |- | Misconduct against Justin Murphy || Suspended for 1 match |- | Melee ||Withdrawn |- |Chance Bateman ||rowspan=4| Melee || Fined $5,000 |- |Peter Everitt || Fined $5,000 |- |Nick Holland || Fined $5,000 |- |Mark Williams || Fined $4,000 |} ===Essendon=== Justin Murphy was suspended for 1 match and melee fines totalled $34,000: {| class="wikitable" |- style="background:#efefef;" ! style="width:150pt;"| Player ! style="width:250pt;"| Charge ! style="width:200pt;"| Outcome |- |rowspan=2|Justin Murphy || Head-butting Simon Beaumont || Suspended for 1 match |- |Melee || Withdrawn |- |Mark Johnson ||rowspan=8| Melee || Fined $6,500 |- |Adam McPhee || Fined $4,500 |- |Dean Solomon || Fined $4,500 |- |Mark McVeigh || Fined $4,000 |- |Dean Rioli || Fined $4,000 |- |Damien Peverill || Fined $3,500 |- |Jason Johnson || Fined $3,500 |- |Andrew Welsh || Fined $3,500 |} ==Match result== {{AFLGameDetailed |title = Round 11, 2004 |date = Saturday, 5 June 2:10 pm |home team = {{AFL Haw}} |home capt = [[Richard Vandenberg]] |home coach = [[Peter Schwab]] |home Q1 = 2.2 (14) |home Q2 = 5.3 (33) |home Q3 = 7.6 (48) |home final = 12.8 (80) |home goals = [[Chance Bateman|Bateman]] 2, [[Peter Everitt|Everitt]] 2, [[Nathan Thompson (Australian footballer)|Thompson]] 2, [[Mark Williams (Australian footballer born 1983)|Williams]] 2, [[Simon Beaumont|Beaumont]], [[Luke Hodge|Hodge]], [[Joel Smith|Smith]], [[Richard Vandenberg|Vandenberg]] |home best = [[Joel Smith|Smith]], [[Luke Hodge|Hodge]], [[Ben Dixon (Australian rules footballer)|Dixon]] |home injuries= |home reports = See [[#Tribunal|Tribunal]] |winner = A |away team = {{AFL Ess}} |away capt = [[James Hird]] |away coach = [[Kevin Sheedy]] |away Q1 = 6.4 (40) |away Q2 = 10.5 (65) |away Q3 = 19.8 (122) |away final = 24.10 (154) |away goals = [[Matthew Lloyd|Lloyd]] 7, [[Scott Lucas (footballer)|Lucas]] 3, [[Justin Murphy (Australian rules footballer)|Murphy]] 2, [[Mark Johnson (footballer)|M. Johnson]] 2, [[Dean Rioli|Rioli]] 2, [[Matthew Allan|Allan]], [[Mark Alvey|Alvey]], [[Mark Bolton|Bolton]], [[Aaron Henneman|Henneman]], [[Jason Johnson (Australian rules footballer)|J. Johnson]], [[Joe Misiti|Misiti]], [[Damien Peverill|Peverill]], [[Dean Solomon|Solomon]] |away best = [[Scott Lucas (footballer)|Lucas]], [[Matthew Lloyd|Lloyd]], [[Dean Solomon|Solomon]], [[Matthew Allan|Allan]], [[Jason Johnson (Australian rules footballer)|J. Johnson]], [[Adam McPhee|McPhee]] |away injuries= |away reports = See [[#Tribunal|Tribunal]] |venue = [[Melbourne Cricket Ground|MCG]] |crowd = 42,682 |report = |umpires = [[Justin Schmitt|Schmitt]], [[Scott Jeffery|Jeffery]], [[Darren Goldspink|Goldspink]] |broadcast = [[Network Ten]] |notes = }} ==Aftermath== Both teams struggled for the remainder of the season. Hawthorn did not win another match until round 19, and finished the season with four wins, narrowly avoiding the [[Wooden spoon (award)|wooden spoon]] to {{AFL Ric}} on percentage. Essendon, meanwhile, won just four more matches for the regular season to qualify for the finals, in eighth place. They defeated fifth-placed {{AFL Mel}} by five points in the first elimination final, but then lost to [[Geelong Football Club|Geelong]] by ten points the following week. In the years following this match, the clubs' fortunes reversed sharply. Essendon dropped to 13th the following season, missing out on the finals for the first time since [[1997 AFL season|1997]], and would not make another finals series until 2009, doing so after they defeated Hawthorn by 17 points in the final round of the [[2009 AFL season|2009 season]].{{cite web|url=http://www.abc.net.au/news/2009-08-29/bombers-beat-hawks-to-finals-berth/1409174|title=Bombers beat Hawks to finals berth|publisher=ABC News ([[Australian Broadcasting Corporation]])|first=Raman|last=Goraya|date=29 August 2009|accessdate=23 December 2016}} It still, however, managed a two-point win over the Hawks early in the 2005 season, courtesy of a controversial goal to [[Dean Solomon]];{{cite web|url=http://www.abc.net.au/news/2005-04-10/bombers-pip-hawks-in-thriller/1548956|title=Bombers pip Hawks in thriller|publisher=ABC News ([[Australian Broadcasting Corporation]])|date=10 April 2005|accessdate=23 December 2016}}{{cite web|url=http://www.foxsports.com.au/news/14-reasons-essendon-hawthorn-hate-each-other/news-story/523f6ef05c6b4d1e17f2930250d84f8f|title=14 reasons Essendon, Hawthorn hate each other|publisher=Fox Sports Australia|first=Daryl|last=Timms|date=24 July 2013|accessdate=23 December 2016}} it marked the Bombers' tenth consecutive victory over the Hawks dating back to 1998.{{cite web|url=http://www.theage.com.au/afl/afl-news/essendon-v-hawthorn-friday-footy-forecast-20130723-2qgev.html|title=Essendon v Hawthorn: Friday footy forecast|publisher=The Age|first=Will|last=Brodie|date=18 July 2013|accessdate=23 December 2016}} Following that, Essendon would not beat Hawthorn again until round seven, 2009, but would beat the Hawks three consecutive times within twelve months, including a resounding 43-point victory in round six, 2010, in which the Hawks copped criticism for a performance described as "embarrassing".{{cite web|url=https://au.news.yahoo.com/thewest/sport/a/7182257/franklin-in-doubt-after-training-injury/|title=Franklin in doubt after training injury|publisher=The West Australian|first=Craig|last=O'Donoghue|date=6 May 2010|accessdate=23 December 2016}} Hawthorn, meanwhile, gradually started to rise up the ladder under new coach [[Alastair Clarkson]], reaching the semi-finals in 2007 and winning the premiership [[2008 AFL Grand Final|the following year]]; it has subsequently won three more premierships, in succession between 2013 and 2015. The clubs have maintained a strong rivalry, but only one match has turned particularly violent since: in the final round of the [[2009 AFL season|2009 season]], with the two sides battling for eighth place on the ladder, a brawl was sparked by a remonstration from a head-high shirtfront from Essendon captain [[Matthew Lloyd]] on Hawthorn midfielder [[Brad Sewell]] at the start of the third quarter, which was to be the turning point in the match. Essendon won by 17 points after trailing by 22 points at the time of the Lloyd-Sewell incident. ==See also== * [[List of sporting scandals]] * [[Battle of Brookvale]] ==References== {{reflist|2}} ==External links== * [https://web.archive.org/web/20111005011914/http://bigpondvideo.com/AFL/14937?Quarters=3 Bigpond TV "Hawks vs Bombers"] – Video clip of [[Network 10|Channel 10]]'s television coverage, replayed on Fox Footy. {{Hawthorn Football Club}} {{Essendon Football Club}} [[Category:2004 Australian Football League season]] [[Category:Australian rules football controversies]] [[Category:Brawls in team sports]] [[Category:Australian Football League games]] [[Category:Essendon Football Club]] [[Category:Hawthorn Football Club]] [[Category:Sports scandals in Australia]]

{{See also|Krylya Sovetov Moscow}} {{Infobox KHL team | team = MHC Krylya Sovetov | colour = #E71410 | colour text = #FFFFFF | logo = [[File:MHCsovietwingslogo2.png|200px]] | name2 = '''MHC Krylya Sovetov''' | nickname = | founded = 2008 | city = [[Moscow]] | arena = [[Dmitrov]] | capacity = 2200 | league = '''[[Minor Hockey League]]''' 2009–2010
*'''[[Russian Major League]]'''
2008 | division = Center | history = | colours = Blue, White, Red | owner = {{flagicon|RUS}} Institute of Light Alloys (VILS) | gm = | coach = Privalov Vadim Nikolaevich | captain = | honors = |affiliates = |website = http://www.hcdmitrov.ru/ }} '''MHC Krylya Sovetov''' ({{lang-ru|МХК Крылья Советов}}; lit. ''Moscow Hockey Club Soviet Wings'') was a professional [[ice hockey]] team based in [[Moscow]], [[Russia]]. The team existed for 2 years after [[PHC Krylya Sovetov]] were expelled from the [[Soviet Wings Sport Palace]] in 2008 and the owner of the arena created a new team. MHC Krylya Sovetov was reunited with PHC Krylya Sovetov in 2010. ==History== ===Controversy=== [[File:MHCsovietwingslogo.png|left]] In 2008, the owner of the [[Soviet Wings Sport Palace]], the All-Russia Institute of Light Alloys (VILS) ({{lang-ru|Всероссийский институт лёгких сплавов (ВИЛС}}) accused [[Krylya Sovetov Moscow|Krylya Sovetov]] of overdue rent payments. This led to the subsequent eviction of the team. The current team left under president [[Aleksandr Tretiak]]'s lead, but Krylya's hockey school, junior subsidiary teams, and other infrastructure opted to remain under the effective ownership of VILS. In light of this, VILS created a new team MHC Krylya Sovetov. MHC Krylya Sovetov's main team did not play in the 2009–10 season since the definitive calendar of games for the 2009–10 season of the [[Russian Major League]] only contained [[PHC Krylya Sovetov]] in the Western Division.{{cite web|title=Высшая лига. Календарь сезона 2009-2010 Дивизион Запад |url=http://fhr.ru/page/vyshaya_liga_kalendar_2009_10_zapad |publisher=Ice Hockey Federation of Russia |accessdate=5 September 2009 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090908104849/http://fhr.ru/page/vyshaya_liga_kalendar_2009_10_zapad |archivedate=September 8, 2009 }}{{cite web|title=Утверждён окончательный календарь первенства Высшей лиги сезона 2009-2010 |url=http://fhr.ru/news/utverzden_okonchatelnyi_kalendar_vyshki_2009-10 |publisher=Ice Hockey Federation of Russia |accessdate=5 September 2009 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090908182134/http://fhr.ru/news/utverzden_okonchatelnyi_kalendar_vyshki_2009-10 |archivedate=September 8, 2009 }} MHC Krylya Sovetov's junior team however played in the newly formed [[Minor Hockey League]]. According to KHL website [[Alexander Medvedev]] contacted both the administration of PHC Krylya Sovetov and MHC Krylya Sovetov and the two clubs with the help of KHL will be reunited into a single organization once again after the split in 2008.{{cite web |url=http://www.khl.ru/news/2010/7/23/27719.html |script-title=ru:КХЛ объединяет "Крылья Советов" в одну структуру |date=23 July 2010 |publisher=[[Kontinental Hockey League]] |accessdate=23 July 2010 |language=Russian}} The reunited team will play their games in Setun, [[Moscow]], where MHC Krylya Sovetov played their games after the 2008 split. The junior team will play in [[Dmitrov]].{{cite web |url=http://www.championat.ru/hockey/news-555395.html |script-title=ru:Объединённые "Крылья" переедут в Сетунь в сентябре |date=27 July 2010 |publisher=Championat.ru |accessdate=27 July 2010 |language=Russian}} ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== *{{ru icon}} [https://web.archive.org/web/20081217070536/http://online.fhr.ru/team.php?tournament=25&team=62 Team Roster and Statistics] {{DEFAULTSORT:Krylya Sovetov}} [[Category:Ice hockey teams in Russia]] [[Category:Sports clubs in Moscow]] {{Europe-icehockey-team-stub}} {{Russian-sport-stub}}

国家网球中心 | nickname = | image = [[File:林萃桥站出口.JPG|250px|Inside]]
[[Image:2008 Olympic Green Tennis Center.JPG|250px]] | fullname = | location = [[Beijing]], China | coordinates = | broke_ground = 2003 | built = | opened = 2007 | renovated = | expanded = 2011 | closed = | demolished = | owner = Beijing Shiao Forest Park Development & Management Limited | operator = Beijing Shiao Forest Park Development & Management Limited | surface = Hard, outdoors | construction_cost = | architect = | structural engineer = | services engineer = | general_contractor = | project_manager = | main_contractors = | former_names =Olympic Green Tennis Center | tenants = [[China Open (tennis)|China Open]] (2009–present) | seating_capacity = 32 400 seats

(Court 2-8/ Court 3-9)
('''''Previous courts name are currently used''''') | dimensions = | scoreboard = |publictransit=[[Lincuiqiao Station]]}} {{coord|40|01|08.88|N|116|22|24.44|E|type:landmark|display=title}} The National Tennis Center ({{zh|s=国家网球中心|t=國家網球中心|p=Guójiā Wǎngqiú Zhōngxīn}}),[http://en.beijing2008.cn/venues/ogt/index.shtml Beijing2008.cn profile.] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080809120241/http://en.beijing2008.cn/venues/ogt/index.shtml |date=9 August 2008 }} is a [[tennis]] centre located in the [[Olympic Green]]. It opened on 1 October 2007. [http://miaobaby.com/olympics/olympic-green-tennis-center-is-officially-delivered-on-national-day/] It hosted the [[Tennis at the 2008 Summer Olympics|tennis]] preliminaries and finals of singles and doubles for men and women at the [[2008 Summer Olympics|Beijing 2008 Olympics]] as well as the [[Paralympic]] [[Wheelchair tennis at the 2008 Summer Paralympics|wheelchair tennis]] competitions. In 2009, it became the home of [[China Open (tennis)|China Open]]. ==General information== The Center is located in [[Beijing]], just {{convert|1.7|miles|km|abbr=on}} from the [[Beijing National Stadium]] (a.k.a. The Birds Nest Stadium). The tennis centre covers an area of {{convert|41.22|acre|m2|abbr=on}} with a floor space of {{convert|285394|sqft|m2|abbr=on}}. The centre currently has 12 competition hard courts and 35 training courts, including 20 hard courts, 10 indoor hard courts, 2 artificial grass courts, 2 indoor clay courts, and a mini hard court. The main court, named Diamond Court, has a capacity of 15,000. The Lotus court, Moon court, and Brad Drewett Court all have 12 stands, which represent pedals of lotus flowers, one of the emblems of the [[2008 Summer Olympics]]. Lotus court has a capacity of 10,000. Moon Court has a capacity of 4,000 and Brad Drewett Court has a capacity of 2,000. The courts have been specially designed for natural air ventilation to reduce the amount of air pollution entering the courts, ensuring optimal health for both athletes and spectators. It also allows the courts to be cooled and with an installation of cooling machines, the courts' temperatures can easily be reduced to five degrees Celsius. Curtains attached to the roofs of the courts also allows them to be cooled in the heat of the sun. The project embodies the concepts of Green Olympics, Hi-Tech Olympics, and People's Olympics. It integrates design experience of world sport architecture and will be a tennis competition venue of the state of the art design in keeping with international standards. In 2009 the [[China Open (tennis)|China Open]], which is an '''[[Association of Tennis Professionals|ATP]]''' [[ATP World Tour 500 series|World Tour 500 series]] event and a '''[[Women's Tennis Association|WTA]]''' [[WTA Premier tournaments|Premiere Mandatory]] tournament, moved its location to this center from its former location, the [[Beijing Tennis Center]]. ==Rename== The National Tennis Center was named as The '''Olympic Green Tennis Center''' or '''Beijing Olympic Green Tennis Court''' ({{zh|s=北京奥林匹克公园网球中心|t=北京奧林匹克公園網球中心|p=Běijīng Àolínpǐkè Gōngyuán Wǎngqiúzhōngxīn}}),[http://en.beijing2008.cn/venues/ogt/index.shtml Beijing2008.cn profile.] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080809120241/http://en.beijing2008.cn/venues/ogt/index.shtml |date=9 August 2008 }} at the [[2008 Summer Olympics|Beijing 2008 Olympics]]. Since it started to host the [[China Open (tennis)|China Open]], the venue was renamed to National Tennis Center in 2009. ==Timeline== ===Before The Olympics=== All courts except for the National Tennis Stadium were opened on 1 October 2007 and were tested between 6 and 20 October 2007 in the [http://www.tennis2007.org/en/ Good Luck Beijing 2007 ITF Pro Circuit], where 36 men and 44 women competed. ===During The Olympics=== [[File:Olympic Green Tennis Centre Interior.jpg|thumb|right|Olympic Green Tennis Center during the [[2008 Summer Olympics]]]] The Courts hosted the 2008 Summer Olympics in Beijing. The following competitions were played:
- [[Tennis at the 2008 Summer Olympics – Men's singles|men's singles]] – 64-player draw
- [[Tennis at the 2008 Summer Olympics – Women's singles|women's singles]] – 64-player draw
- [[Tennis at the 2008 Summer Olympics – Men's doubles|men's doubles]] – 32-player draw
- [[Tennis at the 2008 Summer Olympics – Women's doubles|women's doubles]] – 32-player draw ====The winners==== {| {{MedalistTable|type=Event}} |- | Men's singles

[[Zheng Jie]] |} ===During The Paralympics=== The Courts also hosted the [[Wheelchair Tennis|wheelchair tennis]] competitions of the [[2008 Summer Paralympics]] in Beijing. These were played between 8 and 15 September 2008. 112 athletes (approximately 64-80 male and 32~48 female) were classified into disability group. The competitions played included: *men's singles *women's singles *men's doubles *women's doubles *quads singles *quads doubles ====The winners==== {| {{MedalistTable|type=Event}} |- | Men's singles
{{DetailsLink|Wheelchair tennis at the 2008 Summer Paralympics - Men's singles}} |{{flagIPCmedalist|[[Shingo Kunieda]]|JPN|2008 Summer}} |{{flagIPCmedalist|[[Robin Ammerlaan]]|NED|2008 Summer}} |{{flagIPCmedalist|[[Maikel Scheffers]]|NED|2008 Summer}} |- | Men's doubles

[[Jamie Burdekin]]
[[Peter Norfolk]] |} ==After The Olympics/Paralympics== After the Beijing Olympic and Paralympic games of 2008, the center remained standing. It did not host the 2008 [[China Open (tennis)|China Open]] Tennis tournament, despite rumours it would. However, it became the new home of the China Open from 2009 onwards.[http://www.chinaopen.com.cn/news/2008-12-19/164876.shtml] A new center court, National Tennis Stadium, was completed in 2011. Featuring a retractable roof, this new court possesses a capacity of 15,000 spectators, making it the world's fifth largest tennis stadium by capacity. [[Lincuiqiao Station]] on [[Beijing Subway]] [[Line 8, Beijing Subway|Line 8]] opened in the same year, providing the closest public transport access to the tennis center. ==See also== *[[Tennis in China]] * [[List of tennis stadiums by capacity]] ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== {{commons category|Olympic Green Tennis Centre}} *[http://en.beijing2008.cn/venues/ogt/ Beijing Olympic Green Tennis Center venue site] *[http://www.worldstadiums.com/stadium_pictures/asia/china/beijing_tennis.shtml World stadiums] *[http://wikimapia.org/#lat=40.0198258&lon=116.372112&z=17&l=0&m=b Wikimapia] {{2008 Summer Olympics venues}} {{Olympic venues tennis}} {{Buildings and Structures in Beijing}} [[Category:Venues of the 2008 Summer Olympics]] [[Category:Olympic tennis venues]] [[Category:Tennis venues in China]] [[Category:Sports venues in Beijing]] [[Category:Sports venues completed in 2007]]

{{multiple issues| {{Cleanup|date=June 2010}} {{Refimprove|date=January 2015}}}} {{Use British English|date=July 2013}} {{Use dmy dates|date=May 2011}} {{Infobox building | name = SSE Arena Belfast | image = Odyssey Arena, Belfast - geograph.org.uk - 860741 (cropped).jpg | image_size = 250px | image_alt = | image_caption = Complex seen from Clarendon Dock (c.2008) | former_names = Landmark Millennium Project {{small|(planning/construction)}}
Odyssey Centre {{small|(2000–13)}} | location = [[Titanic Quarter]] | coordinates = {{Coord|54|36|15|N|5|54|54|W|type:landmark|display=inline,title}} | address = 2 [[Queen's Quay, Belfast|Queen's Quay]]
[[Belfast]] BT3 9QQ
[[Northern Ireland]] | groundbreaking_date = {{Start date|1998|06|df=y}} | opened_date = {{Start date|2000|12|02|df=y}} | inauguration_date = {{Start date|2001|11|29|df=y}} | renovation_date = 2015 | closing_date = | demolition_date = | cost = £120 million | ren_cost = £3 million | owner = Odyssey Trust Company Ltd. | seating_capacity = 2,276 {{small|(SSE Arena, Belfast)}} | architect = Consarc Design Group | architecture_firm = | developer = Delap & Waller, Tavakoli Associates | engineer = | structural_engineer = Ballykine | services_engineer = RPS Group | civil_engineer = | other_designers = Teather Walls Architects | quantity_surveyor = | main_contractor = Farrans Construction, Gilbert-Ash | ren_architect = HJ Lyons Architects | ren_firm = | ren_engineer = | ren_str_engineer = Turley & Associates | ren_serv_engineer = RPS Group | ren_civ_engineer = | ren_oth_designers = | ren_qty_surveyor = | ren_contractor = | ren_awards = | rooms = | parking = 1,500 spaces | client = [[Belfast Giants]] {{small|([[Elite Ice Hockey League|EIHL]])}} | website = | embedded = }} The '''Odyssey Complex''' (currently known as the '''SSE Arena Belfast''' for sponsorship reasons) is a sports and entertainment complex located within the Titanic Quarter in [[Belfast]], [[Northern Ireland]]. The complex originated in 1992 and came into fruition in June 1998. It opened in December 2000, with expansions opening in March and May 2001. The complex consists of: a multipurpose arena, science centre and shopping centre. The shopping centre houses a movie theatre and bowling alley, alongside a selection of restaurants. ==History== [[File:Odyssey Arena logo.png|thumb|left|150px|Arena logo used from 2000–15]] The Odyssey Centre was 50% funded by a £45m grant from the [[Millennium Commission]] as part of the Landmark Project for Northern Ireland with matched funding from the [[Department of Education (Northern Ireland)|Department of Education Northern Ireland]], the Sheridan Group and the [[Sports Council for Northern Ireland]]. The application to the Millennium Commission was led by the [[Ulster Museum]], who wished to develop a science centre and teamed up with Peter Curistan who wished to develop an [[IMAX]], and then led the development of the Arena with L&R leisure who were the consultants. The name "Odyssey", was to symbolise the 'journey of discovery' that would be the science centre and Michael Montgomery, a young 14 year old at the time came up with the name. The complex adopted the name, and the Science Centre became W5. The arena opened in 2000, W5 on 31 March 2001 with the Pavilion opening a few months later. The Odyssey is quoted to have cost £120 million on completion. Odyssey was held in Trust by the Odyssey Trust Company with leases to SMG/Sheridan for the Arena, Sheridan for the Pavilion and the National Museums NI for W5. In 2011 Odyssey Trust took over the Arena. In 2011 The Odyssey Pavilion which was owned by The Sheridan Group went into administration, and the building went under control of KPMG temporarily until the energy company [[SSE plc|SSE]] purchased it. It is managed by The Odyssey Trust. ==Facilities== [[File:Odyssey Arena 03.10.2010.jpg|thumb|200px|left|Interior bowl of the arena before an ice hockey match, 2010]] ===SSE Arena, Belfast=== Formerly the '''Odyssey Arena''' from 2000 to 2015. [[Northern Ireland|Northern Ireland's]] biggest indoor arena, with a capacity of 10,000+ for concerts,{{cite web|url=http://www.theodyssey.co.uk/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=53&Itemid=58 |title=The SSE Arena, Belfast home of the Belfast Giants |publisher=Theodyssey.co.uk |date= |accessdate=2015-10-03}} hosts concerts and sporting events such as [[Belfast Giants]] games. On 25 June 2015, it was announced the Arena would undergo a £3 million refurbishment and become the SSE Arena on September 4, 2015. The naming rights will last for 10 years.{{cite web|last=Cromie |first=Claire |url=http://www.belfasttelegraph.co.uk/news/northern-ireland/belfasts-odyssey-to-be-renamed-the-sse-arena-in-naming-rights-agreement-31329389.html |title=Belfast's Odyssey to be renamed the SSE Arena in naming rights agreement |publisher=BelfastTelegraph.co.uk |date=2015-06-25 |accessdate=2015-10-03}} ====Sports==== World champion boxer [[Carl Frampton]] has fought at the Odyssey several times. The venue has also hosted a number of [[World Wrestling Entertainment]] live events including ''[[WWE Raw|RAW]]'' and ''[[WWE Friday Night SmackDown|SmackDown!]]''. WWE visits the Odyssey at least once a year. It hosted [[UFC 72|UFC 72: Victory]] on 16 June 2007. Since 2008, it has played host to the [[Premier League Darts]]. On 2 October 2010, the [[Boston Bruins]] faced the [[Belfast Giants]] Selects in an [[NHL Challenge]] match. ===Odyssey Pavilion=== [[File:The Odyssey - Belfast.jpg|thumb|right|200px|Entrance to the Odyssey Pavilion, Belfast]] The Odyssey Pavilion houses multiple shops and entertainment venues. Notable examples include The Odyssey Bowl (bowling alley), Odyssey Cinema and The Box A '''Sheridan [[IMAX]]''' operated in the complex from 2000 until 2007, with its former location remaining vacant since. ===W5=== [[File:Dsc 0154-luckey-llcs-conflicted-copy-2014-07-11.jpg|thumb|right|200px|Luckey Climber, 2014]] W5 stands for "Who, What, Where, When, Why"....all the questions asked in science. W5 was developed by Dr Sally Montgomery, the Ulster Museum's Project Director (and then founding CEO) with the exhibitions being designed by Hands On Inc, Florida USA and Ontario Science Centre, Canada. W5 has roughly 250 interactive exhibits, along with 6 themed exhibitions, in 3500 sq metres of exhibition space, workshop space and lecture theatre.{{Cite web|url=https://w5online.co.uk/explore|title=Explore W5｜Over 250 Interactive Exhibits｜W5 Belfast|date=2018-07-06|website=W5|language=en-gb|others=W5|access-date=2018-07-09}} W5 was a wholly owned subsidiary of the National Museums Northern Ireland until 31 March 2012 when it became a subsidiary of Odyssey Trust. W5 has won a huge number of awards including Best Visitor Attraction, several times. In 2013, W5 opened 'Climbit' (pronounced "climb it"),{{Cite web|url=https://w5online.co.uk/explore/climbit|title=ClimbIt｜Multi-Storey Climbing Structure｜W5 Belfast|date=2018-07-06|website=W5|language=en-gb|others=W5|access-date=2018-07-10}} the biggest [[Luckey Climber]] in Europe where small children can climb up twelve metres in total safety. ==Future== In October 2009, The Odyssey Trust sought planning permission for a £100m extension plan. The plans include 800 residential units, two hotels, a promenade, shops, additional leisure facilities and a [[multi-storey car park]].{{cite web|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/uk_news/northern_ireland/8295078.stm |title=UK | Northern Ireland | £100m Odyssey site revamp planned |publisher=BBC News |date=2009-10-07 |accessdate=2015-10-03}} On 29 November 2013, the owners of the Odyssey won planning permission for an extension to include hotels, shops and apartments creating around 1,000 new jobs. Work is due to start immediately, with around 800 people set to work on construction of the scheme – described as the biggest redevelopment in Belfast in years. Odyssey Trust's plan is to build next to the existing Odyssey Arena and Pavilion as part of the restart of the Belfast master plan. In October 2017, it was announced that Planning Permission had been submitted to transform the Complex in a £10m refurbishment. Plans include a new entrance to the Odyssey Pavilion, upgrade of Public Realm and reconfiguration of existing retail units. Phase two will see improved visitor access and greater use of the central open space. ==Awards== The Odyssey was short-listed for 'International Large Venue of the Year' (Outside of North America) in the 2005 Pollstar Concert Industry Awards, making it one of the top six major concert venues in the world.[http://www.pollstaronline.com/CIC2006/Awards17/awardscategories.htm ] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20060420205127/http://www.pollstaronline.com/CIC2006/Awards17/awardscategories.htm |date=20 April 2006 }}{{cite web |url=http://www.odysseyarena.com/latestnews-archive.asp?newsID=163 |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2006-07-01 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://archive.is/20120907002525/http://www.odysseyarena.com/latestnews-archive.asp?newsID=163 |archivedate=7 September 2012 |df=dmy-all }} ==Transport== The SSE Arena is located in the Titanic Quarter, just a 10/25minute walk from the City Centre. [[Translink (Northern Ireland)|Translink NI]] Metro service 26, 26A, 26B, 26C, 600A and 600B stop directly outside the Arena and depart from Donegall Square North, just outside the Visit [[Belfast]] Welcome Centre. The [[Northern Ireland Railways]] [[Titanic Quarter railway station]] is only a 5-minute walk away from the Arena and [[Titanic Belfast]] visitor centre. ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== {{Commons category|Odyssey Arena, Belfast}} * [http://www.ssearenabelfast.com SSE Arena, Belfast Official Website] * [http://www.odysseypavilion.co.uk Odyssey Pavilion Official Website] * [http://www.w5online.co.uk W5 Official Website] {{Indoor arenas UK}} {{Elite Ice Hockey League Venues}} {{EAA members}} [[Category:Buildings and structures completed in 2001]] [[Category:Music venues completed in 2001]] [[Category:Sports venues completed in 2001]] [[Category:Indoor ice hockey venues in the United Kingdom]] [[Category:Buildings and structures in Belfast]] [[Category:Indoor arenas in Northern Ireland]] [[Category:Music venues in Belfast]] [[Category:Buildings and structures celebrating the third millennium]] [[Category:Concert halls in Northern Ireland]] [[Category:2001 establishments in Northern Ireland]] [[Category:Darts venues]] [[Category:MTV Europe Music Awards venues]]

{{Hatnote|Not to be confused with [[Riverside International Speedway]], a short track in Nova Scotia}} {{Multiple issues| {{confusing|date=December 2016}} {{tone|date=July 2016}} }} {{Motorsport venue |Name = Riverside International Raceway |Nickname = The dusty place |Image = [[Image:RIRLogo.jpg|150px]]
[[File:Riverside International Raceway 1980 and 1967.svg|270px]] |Location = California 60 and Day Street
22255 Eucalyptus Ave [[Moreno Valley, California]] 92388 |Broke_ground = January 1957 |Opened = September 22, 1957 |Closed = July 2, 1989 |Owner = (1983–1989) [[Fritz Duda]] |Operator = (1983–1989) Fritz Duda |Construction_cost= [[United States dollar|$625,000]] |Architect = William L. Duquette |Former_names = Riverside International Motor Raceway (1957–1960) |Events ='''[[NASCAR]] [[Nextel Cup|Winston Cup]]'''
[[Winston Western 500]] (1974–1987)
[[Budweiser 400]] (1970–1988)
'''[[International Motor Sports Association|IMSA]]'''
[[Los Angeles Times Grand Prix]]
'''[[Formula One]]'''
[[United States Grand Prix]] (1960)
'''[[IndyCar World Series]]'''
AirCal 500 / L.A. Times 500 (1981–1983) |Capacity = Varies by race and track layout |Layout1 = Long Course |Length_km = 5.3 |Length_mi = 3.3 |Layout2 = NASCAR Course |Length_km2= 4.22 |Length_mi2= 2.62 |Surface2 = Asphalt |Turns2 = 9 |Record_time2 = 118.484 miles per hour |Record_driver2= [[Ricky Rudd]] |Record_team2 = |Record_year2 = 1988 |Record_class2 = [[NASCAR]] |Layout3 = Short Course |Length_km3= 4.09 |Length_mi3= 2.54 |Layout4 = Drag Strip |Length_km4= 0.7 |Length_mi4= 0.4 |Layout5 = Oval |Length_km5= 0.8 |Length_mi5= 0.5 |Surface6 = Asphalt }} '''Riverside International Raceway''' (sometimes known as '''Riverside''', '''RIR''', or '''Riverside Raceway''') was a motorsports [[race track]] and [[Road racing|road course]] in the [[Moreno Valley, California|Moreno Valley]] area, a suburb just east of [[Riverside, California]]. Riverside was a hot, dusty place. It was at times, also a dangerous place, yet it is remembered with affection by drivers and fans alike, as the home of road racing in southern California. It was also considered one of the USA's finest tracks.{{cite web |last1=Parker |first1=C. |title=One of America's finest tracks |url=http://www.racingcircuits.info/north-america/usa/riverside.html#.W_D4sIFKi02 |website=racingcircuirs.com |accessdate=18 November 2018}}The track was in operation from September 22, 1957, to July 2, 1989, with the last race, The Budweiser 400,{{cite web |title=Budweiser 400 88 |url=https://www.racing-reference.info/race/1988_Budweiser_400/W |website=racingreference.com |accessdate=17 November 2018}} won by Rusty Wallace,{{cite web |title=Racing Reference |url=https://www.racing-reference.info/driver/Rusty_Wallace |website=racingreference.com |accessdate=17 November 2018}} held in 1988. After that final race, a shortened version of the circuit was kept open for car clubs and special events until 1989.{{cite web |last1=Hansen |first1=B. |title=After the last race |url=http://www.racingcircuits.info/north-america/usa/riverside.html#.W_Bq9oFKi00 |website=racingcircuitsinfo.com}} ==History== [[File:RiversideInternationalRaceway 1988.jpg|thumb|right|The final NASCAR race at Riverside in 1988]] In the beginning it was originally called '''The Riverside International Motor Raceway'''. It was built in early 1957 by a company called West Coast Automotive Testing Corp.. The head of West Coast Auto Testing was a man by the name of Rudy Cleye, from Los Angeles, who had previously raced in Europe. However the building of the raceway met with funding difficulties early on and a businessman by the name of John Edgar provided a much needed cash bailout. This action prevented any halt in the track's construction.{{cite news |last1=Glick |first1=Shav |title=RIR History |url=http://articles.latimes.com/1988-08-07/sports/sp-405_1_race-track/4 |accessdate=17 November 2018 |publisher=L.A.Times |date=Aug 7, 1988}} The first weekend of scheduled races in September 1957, a California Sports Car Club event, John Lawrence of Pasadena, California, lost his life. Lawrence, a former Cal Club member, piloting a 1500 cc Production champion, went off at Turn 5 (later designated Turn 8). With no crash barrier in place, and no rollbar on the car, Lawrence's MGA went up the sand embankment, then rolled back onto the track. Though Lawrence survived the incident, and appeared only slightly injured, he died later at the hospital of a brain injury.{{cite web |last1=Stahler |first1=Tom |title=First death at RIR |url=https://www.drivingline.com/articles/the-legend-of-riverside-raceway/ |website=drivingline.com |accessdate=18 November 2018}} The second major event at the track, in November 1957, was a sports car race featuring some of the top drivers of the day, including [[Carroll Shelby]], [[Masten Gregory]] and [[Ken Miles]]. Another driver entered was an inexperienced local youngster named [[Dan Gurney]], who had been offered the opportunity to drive a powerful but ill-handling 4.9-liter Ferrari after better-known drivers such as Shelby and Miles had rejected it. Shelby led early but spun and fell back. Gurney assumed the lead and led for much of the event. Shelby, driving furiously to catch up, finally overtook Gurney late in the race and won. Gurney's performance caught the eye of North American [[Ferrari]] importer [[Luigi Chinetti]], who arranged for Gurney to drive a factory-supported Ferrari at [[24 Hours of Le Mans|Le Mans]] in 1958, effectively launching the Californian's European career.http://www.racingcircuits.info/north-america/usa/riverside.html#.W_Da2YFKi00 Footage exists of classic races like the 1986 [[Los Angeles Times Grand Prix]] in which the [[Chevy Corvette]] of [[Doc Bundy]], attempting a three-wide pass, hit the [[Ford Probe]] of [[Lyn St. James]] and the [[Jaguar (car)|Jaguar]] of [[Chip Robinson]] at Turn 1. St. James' car caught fire and Chip Robinson nearly cartwheeled into the crowd. St. James survived the flames and Robinson escaped uninjured within the track bounds.{{cite web |last1=Cider |first1=Frank |title=Riverside International |url=http://oscarbyalpinestars.blogspot.com/2009/12/riverside-international-raceway.html |website=oscarbyalpinestars.com}} The track was known as a relatively dangerous course, with its long, downhill back straightaway and brake-destroying, relatively slow 180-degree Turn 9 at the end. During the 1965 Motor Trend 500 NASCAR race, Indycar great [[A. J. Foyt]] suffered a brake failure at the end of the straight, shot off the road and went end-over-end through the infield at high speed. Crash crews assumed Foyt was dead at the scene, until fellow driver [[Parnelli Jones]] noticed a twitch of movement. Ford factory sports car driver Ken Miles was killed there in a testing accident in August 1966 when his Ford sports car prototype (known as the J-car) became aerodynamically unstable and flew out of control at the end of the back straight. In December 1968, American Formula 5000 champion [http://www.motorsportmagazine.com/database/drivers/lou-sell Dr. Lou Sell] crashed and overturned in Turn 9 on the first lap of the Rex Mays 300 Indianapolis-style race, suffering near-fatal burns. In January 1967, Canadian driver [[Billy Foster]] crashed at Turn 9 during a practice-session just prior to the start of qualifying for the Motor Trend 500 NASCAR race. These accidents and others caused track management to reconfigure Turn 9, giving the turn a dogleg approach and a much wider radius (a water improvement also closed the raceway for a few months).http://oscarbyalpinestars.blogspot.com/2009/12/riverside-international-raceway.html In January 1964, Riverside also claimed the life of 1962–'63 NASCAR champion [[Joe Weatherly]], who refused to wear a shoulder harness and wore his lap belt loosely. Weatherly died when he lost control entering Turn 6, hitting the steel barrier almost broadside and had his head snapped out the window against the barrier. Nevertheless, in 1983 Turn 9 was the site of the only fatality in [[International Motor Sports Association|IMSA]] GTP history. In the 1983 Times Grand Prix, [[Rolf Stommelen]]'s Joest-constructed [[Porsche 935]] lost its rear wing at the Dogleg and hit two freeway-type barriers sending it into a horrific roll at Turn 9. https://www.gtplanet.net/forum/threads/riverside-international-raceway-riverside-california.342098/ When the racetrack was proposed in the mid-1950s, Riverside International Motor Raceway (as it was called at the time) was planned to ultimately be {{convert|5.0|mi|km}} long, but the club extension was never constructed and the track's final length (after Turn 9 was adjusted in 1969, engineered by David Berg, to a 10 degree banked sweeper) was {{convert|3.3|mi|km}}. [[File:RIR-tickets.gif|thumb|RIR tickets]] In January 1964, Riverside also claimed the life of 1962–'63 NASCAR champion [[Joe Weatherly]], who refused to wear a shoulder harness and wore his lap belt loosely. Weatherly died when he lost control entering Turn 6, hitting the steel barrier almost broadside and had his head snapped out the window against the barrier. Nevertheless, in 1983 Turn 9 was the site of the only fatality in [[International Motor Sports Association|IMSA]] GTP history. In the 1983 Times Grand Prix, [[Rolf Stommelen]]'s Joest-constructed [[Porsche 935]] lost its rear wing at the Dogleg and hit two freeway-type barriers sending it into a horrific roll at Turn 9. https://www.gtplanet.net/forum/threads/riverside-international-raceway-riverside-california.342098/ When the racetrack was proposed in the mid-1950s, Riverside International Motor Raceway (as it was called at the time) was planned to ultimately be {{convert|5.0|mi|km}} long, but the club extension was never constructed and the track's final length (after Turn 9 was adjusted in 1969, engineered by David Berg, to a 10 degree banked sweeper) was {{convert|3.3|mi|km}}. Of the entire road course races run at RIR, there was one that was run in a counter-clockwise direction, sometime around 1960. In 1966 Dan Gurney tested his first Eagle racing car on a shorter, counter-clockwise version of the track tailored specifically for his car's Indianapolis-specific left-turn oiling system. The test caused Gurney to ask track president Les Richter to hold an Indianapolis-style race there. From 1967 to 1969 the Rex Mays 300 served as the season-ending [[United States Auto Club|USAC]] Indianapolis-car race.{{cite web |last1=Miller |first1=Joe |url=https://cmsracing.com/champion/forums/showthread.php?30510-MNRL-Season-1-Race-6-information-Riverside-Int-(Jan-10th) |website=cmsracing.com |accessdate=24 November 2018}} [[ESPN]] taped the June 12, 1988, Budweiser 400 race at RIR and caught racer [[Ruben Garcia (NASCAR driver)|Ruben Garcia]] crashing hard off turn 9 and his car went through two cement barriers before coming to rest near a [[catch fence]] where fans were sitting. He was not injured, though, and neither were the race fans. After 14 years of NASCAR as a driver and later a car owner, [[Richard Childress]] won his first NASCAR race in 1983, when [[Ricky Rudd]] drove his #3 [[Piedmont Airlines (1948-1989)|Piedmont Airlines]] Chevrolet to victory in the 1983 Budweiser 400k. From 1981 until 1987, NASCAR's championship race was at Riverside. The [[United States Automobile Club|USAC]] Championship Trail also held their season ending race from 1967 to 1969. Riverside was home to track announcer [[Sandy Reed (track announcer)|Sandy Reed]] and (along with former LA Rams player Les Richter) [[Roy Hord Jr.]] NASCAR Team owners [[Roger Penske]] and [[Rick Hendrick]] drove a select few races at Riverside in their own cars. Penske won a Winston West race in 1963, while In the final race in 1988, Hendrick got out of the car and let [[Elliott Forbes-Robinson]] take over.{{cite web |last1=Hansen |first1=B. |title=After the last race |url=http://www.racingcircuits.info/north-america/usa/riverside.html#.W_Bq9oFKi00 |website=racingcircuitsinfo.com}} The [[Winston Western 500]] came to be known as the signature event at the track. Initially (1963-1981) this race was held in January as the [[Monster_Energy_NASCAR_Cup_Series#Winston_Cup|Winston Cup Series]] season opener, but beginning in 1982 NASCAR elected to start the season with the [[Daytona 500]]. From 1981-1987 the Winston Western 500 was held in November as the final race of the season.https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Winston_Western_500 Riverside also hosted [[drag racing]] events. Between 1961 and 1969, the [[Hot Rod Magazine Championship Drag Races]], "one of the most significant drag racing events" of that era, were held at RIR.Taylor, Thom. Untitled item in ''Hot Rod Magazine'', February 2017, p. 11. The championship offered a US$37,000 prize, greater even than a [[National Hot Rod Association]] national event prize at the time.Taylor, p. 11. ==The Four Courses of Riverside== The track was built to accommodate several different configurations, depending on the type of car and race length. The three options on Riverside Raceway were the long course ({{convert|3.27|mi|km}}), the short course ({{convert|2.5|mi|km}}), and the [[NASCAR]] ({{convert|2.62|mi|km}}) course. The original racetrack had a {{convert|1.1|mi|km|adj=on}} backstretch from 1957 to 1968. When the track was redesigned in 1969, Turn 9 was reconfigured with a wider radius and banked with a dogleg approach added, to reduce strain on the cars' brakes. The fourth track configuration was a [[drag racing]] strip. Before a racing event at RIR, track crews added [[traffic cone|traffic pylons]] to close off sections of the track. The closed sections were determined by the specific course and cars used during any given race. Throughout it's history, various other track configurations were used to adapt the track for events such as off-road and motorcycle events.{{cite web |last1=Kettle |first1=Tom |title=RIR configurations |url=http://www.racingcircuits.info/north-america/usa/riverside.html#.W_DQMoFKi00 |website=racingcircuits.info |accessdate=18 November 2018}} '''Diagram notes''': The long course had the {{convert|1.1|mi|km|adj=on}} backstretch between turns 8 & 9. This version was used primarily for the ''[[Los Angeles Times]]'' Grand Prix, although the long course was also used for [[American open-wheel car racing|Indy car racing]] in the mid-1980s. When the 1969 version was built, the dogleg was added so as to ease the transition into Turn 9 (the track had seen numerous brake failure-induced accidents approaching Turn 9, and this change was made as a safety measure).
In the short course, the track would use turn '''7A''' rather than 8. The "Turn 7-7A" configuration effectively shortened the back straight to just over one-half mile in length. The NHRA drag strip ran south to north on the backstretch from the runoff to the Bosch Bridge (not shown in diagram), which crossed over the track about halfway between turns 8 & 9. File:Riverside International Raceway 1980 and 1967.svg|left|Riverside International Raceway with & without dogleg. File:Riverside International Raceway 1980.svg|right|The drag strip is in light blue and ran north to the Bosch bridge (bridge not shown). ==Movies and television== Due to its proximity to the Southern California entertainment industry, RIR was a frequent filming location for Hollywood movies, television series and commercials. Scenes from the television shows ''[[CHiPs]]'', ''[[Simon and Simon]]'', ''[[The Rockford Files]]'', ''[[Knight Rider (1982 TV series)|Knight Rider]]'', and the [[HBO]] program ''[[Super Dave Osborne]]'' were shot on location at RIR. The [[Television film|television movie]] adaptation of ''[[Gemini Man]]'', ''Riding With Death'', featured as an experiment on the television show ''[[Mystery Science Theater 3000]]'', also contains footage of racing at Riverside.{{cn|date=November 2018}} RIR was extensively featured in the 1961 telefilm "The Quick and the Dead," an episode of the series [[Route 66 (TV series)|''Route 66'']]. The episode stars [[Martin Milner]] and [[George Maharis]], and guest stars [[Harvey Korman]], [[Regis Toomey]], and [[Betsy Jones-Moreland]]. Milner races a 1960 powder-blue [[Chevrolet Corvette]] in the film. Film shoots at RIR included scenes from: ''[[Good Guys Wear Black]]'' (1978) ''[[The Betsy]]'' (1978), ''[[Fireball 500]]'' (1966), ''[[Grand Prix (1966 film)|Grand Prix]]'' (1966), ''[[The Killers (1964 film)|The Killers]]'' (1964), ''[[The Love Bug]]'' (1968), ''[[On the Beach (1959 film)|On the Beach]]'' (1959), ''[[Roadracers (1959 film)|Roadracers]]'' (1959), ''[[Speedway (1968 film)|Speedway]]'' (1968), ''[[Stacey (1973 film)|Stacey]]'' (1973), ''[[Thunder Alley (film)|Thunder Alley]]'' (1967), ''[[Winning]]'' (1969), and ''[[Viva Las Vegas]]'' (1964).{{Citation | last =Rice | first =Jerry | year =2009 | title =Starring Role; Riverside's Location Just Outside Hollywood | periodical =Riverside Magazine | publisher =Fred H. Hamilton | volume =2 | issue =3 | page =26 | issn =}} ===Use in gaming=== The track was used in [[Sierra Entertainment]]'s ''[[NASCAR Legends]]'', ''[[NASCAR Heat]]'' and later was converted to ''[[NASCAR 4]]'', ''[[NASCAR Racing 2002 Season]]'', ''[[NASCAR Racing 2003 Season|2003]]'' and ''[[rFactor]]''. Riverside has also been featured in ''[[Indianapolis 500: Evolution]]'' for the Xbox 360. ==Closure and transformation into a shopping mall== RIR, headed by former [[Los Angeles Rams]] player [[Les Richter]] sold the property to real estate developer Fritz Duda in 1983. The irony is that Duda had once been a turn announcer for NASCAR's broadcasting arm [[Motor Racing Network]], and many felt racing would long be a part of the Riverside landscape. 1988 was the final year of racing for Riverside International Raceway. On June 12, 1988, NASCAR held its final race at RIR – a race won by [[Rusty Wallace]] (a caution flag was out for [[Ruben Garcia (NASCAR driver)|Ruben Garcia]] when he came off Turn 9 and lost control of his car and hit a wall, missing the grandstands). In 1989, the track was modified from turn 7A to the back straight. The modified track was called '''Riverside Regional Raceway''' and continued to be used for club events. After [[SCORE International]] held its last race, the track finally closed its gates after 32 years of racing. Fritz Duda turned the "House that [[Dan Gurney]] built" into a [[shopping mall]] which opened in 1992. The [[Moreno Valley Mall|Moreno Valley Mall at Towngate]] is on the northern end of the former raceway property and homes now occupy the southern end of what was the old racetrack (where [[Tim Richmond]] and [[Dale Earnhardt]] raced). In a 1994 topographical map, the remains of Riverside's Turn 9 and a wall were still visible. However, today nothing is left of RIR except for [[memorabilia]] from the racetrack. The old Administration Building remained until 2005, when it was torn down to make way for a complex of town homes. Numerous streets in the neighborhood to the east of the Moreno Mall are named after racing identities, such as [[Cale Yarborough|Yarborough]] Drive, [[Dan Gurney|Gurney]] Place, [[Mark Donohue|Donohue]] Court, [[John Surtees|Surtees]] Court, [[Geoff Brabham|Brabham]] Street, [[Mario Andretti|Andretti]] Street and [[Roger Penske|Penske]] Street. When Riverside closed in 1989, it followed in the footsteps of [[Ontario Motor Speedway]] (in nearby [[Ontario, California|Ontario]]), which closed in 1980, and followed by [[Ascot Park (speedway)|Ascot Park]] in [[Gardena, California|Gardena]] in 1991. In the 1990s, two new circuits opened: [[Auto Club Speedway]] in nearby [[Fontana, California|Fontana]] in 1997, and [[Toyota Speedway at Irwindale]] (now the [[Irwindale Event Center]]) in 1999 and is in danger of meeting the same fate as Riverside. Both tracks, like Riverside, have been used for filming. In 2003, the remainder of the old Riverside International Raceway was torn up. The sign that was at [[California State Route 60|California 60]] and Day Street was removed to make way for a [[Lowe's]] warehouse and Turn 9 of the old track is now home to houses. In 2003, plans were announced to build a {{convert|3|mi|km|adj=on}} road course with a similar design to the famed Riverside layout in [[Merced, California]]. The track would have been known as the [[Riverside Motorsports Park]], but the project was abandoned in 2009.{{cite news|url=http://www.mercedsunstar.com/167/story/967136.html=Merced|title=Riverside Motorsports Park CEO says plan for track is dead|date=2009-07-24|author=Reilly, Corinne}}{{dead link|date=April 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} ==Races held at Riverside International Raceway== [[File:Riverside Raceway by deviantmike423.png|thumb|Nascar in the esses at RIR 1983.]] *The NASCAR [[NEXTEL Cup|Winston Cup Series]] and Winston West: Motor Trend 500, NASCAR [[Winston Western 500]], and [[Budweiser 400|NAPA/Budweiser 400K]] (The Cup and West series raced together in those races.) *The [[Champ Car|PPG Indy Car World Series]]: [[Air California|AirCal 500]] / L.A. Times 500 (1981–1983) *The [[1976 Riverside 400]] *[[United States Automobile Club|USAC]] Championship Trail ([[American Championship Car Racing|Indycar]]) Rex Mays 300 (1967–1969) *The [[Los Angeles Times Grand Prix]] of Endurance *The [[1960 United States Grand Prix]] *(Unofficial) 24 hours of Riverside, testing the [[Chevy Corvair]] *The first [[International Race of Champions|IROC]] race was held in Oct. of 1973.{{cite web |last1=Bechtel |first1=Harry |title=IROC @ Riverside |url=http://articles.latimes.com/1997-06-18/news/ss-4479_1_riverside-international-raceway |website=latimes.com |accessdate=17 November 2018}} *[[NHRA]] [[drag racing]] in the mid sixties. *[[SCORE International]] Off Road World Championships, the last one was held in August 1988. *[[International Motor Sports Association|IMSA]] Car races [[Sports Car Club of America (SCCA) Regional & National amateur races, and professional]] ([[Trans-Am, Can-Am Series]]) car races *[[Rex Mays|Rex Mays 300]] *[[American Motorcycle Association|AMA]] motorcycle racing *[[United States Road Racing Championship|United States Road Race Championship]] (USRRC) SCCA series for professional racing drivers 1963-1968 (RIR 1964-1965) ==See also== * [[Motorsport Arena Oschersleben]], a current German racing circuit with a similar but smaller (3.67 km/2.29 mi) layout *[[Riverside International Automotive Museum]] * ==References== {{reflist|30em}} ==Further reading== *''Riverside Raceway, Palace Of Speed'' by [[Dick Wallen (Book author)|Dick Wallen]] *''Riverside International Raceway'' by Pete Lyons * Motorsport Memorial entry on Rolf Stommelen (2005), [http://www.motorsportmemorial.org/focus.php?db=ct&n=228 motorsportmemorial.org]. Retrieved February 1, 2005. * Motorsport Memorial entry on Billy Foster (1966), [http://www.motorsportmemorial.org/focus.php?db=ct&n=464 motorsportmemorial.org] * Articles about Riverside Int'l Raceway: [http://articles.latimes.com/keyword/riverside-international-raceway] ==External links== {{Commons category|Riverside International Raceway}} *[http://RiversideInternationalRaceway.com Riverside International Automotive Museum] *[http://LegendsofRiverside.com Riverside International Automotive Museum's Annual Film Festival & Gala] *[http://www.fsheff.com/ Riverside International Raceway's Picture Pages from Frank Sheffield, a former RIR corner worker] *[https://www.racing-reference.info/tracks/Riverside_International_Raceway| NASCAR track history] {{Formula One circuits}} {{World Sportscar Championship circuits}} {{Can-Am circuits}} {{IMSA GT circuits}} {{USAC tracks}} {{USAC Stock Car racetracks}} {{Champ Car tracks}} {{International Race of Champions tracks}} {{NASCAR Sprint Cup Series racetracks}} {{NASCAR K&N Pro Series racetracks}} {{NASCAR Elite Division Southwest racetracks}} {{Coord|33|56|00.2|N|117|16|20.2|W|display=title}} [[Category:Motorsport venues in California]] [[Category:Defunct drag racing venues]] [[Category:Defunct motorsport venues in the United States]] [[Category:Defunct sports venues in California]] [[Category:Buildings and structures in Riverside, California]] [[Category:Sports venues in Riverside, California]] [[Category:Sports venues completed in 1957]] [[Category:1957 establishments in California]] [[Category:1989 disestablishments in California]] [[Category:Defunct companies based in the Greater Los Angeles Area]] [[Category:Champ Car circuits]] [[Category:Formula One circuits]] [[Category:International Race of Champions tracks]] [[Category:NASCAR races at Riverside International Raceway]] [[Category:IMSA GT Championship circuits]] [[Category:United States Grand Prix]]

revision.comment: Added his latest efforts in the industry
revision.text:
In 1986, '''Ron Shandler''' began publishing the ''Baseball Forecaster'', an annual publication focused on applying [[sabermetrics]] to fantasy baseball, and founder of [http://baseballhq.com Baseball HQ], a website with the same focus. Shandler has an MBA from Hofstra University.
Shandler is seen as a revolutionary thinker in both sabermetrics and fantasy baseball.{{Citation needed|date=January 2009}} Among his innovations in fantasy baseball are:
*'''[[LIMA Plan]]''' - Which stands for Low Investment Mound Aces, is a draft strategy for traditional 4x4 Rotisserie leagues. LIMA is named after pitcher [[José Lima]], who was exemplified by the strategy. The strategy includes spending a maximum of $60 out of your $260 budget on pitching. No more than $30 on saves. Have your pitchers use as few innings as your league rules allow. Look to buy pitchers with strong strikeout-to-walk ratios, high strikeout per inning ratios and low home run per inning ratios. Spend the rest of your budget on hitting.{{Citation needed|date=January 2009}} * '''Strand Rate''' - The percentage of baserunners a pitcher allows who fail to score (''[[Baseball Prospectus]]'' has a similar statistic, [http://www.baseballprospectus.com/glossary/index.php?mode=viewstat&stat=231 Bequeathed Runs Prevented]). Shandler discovered that 72 percent of baserunners on average never cross the plate, so if a pitcher has a higher or lower strand rate there's a chance it will affect his ERA in the opposite direction in the future.<ref>{{cite news | first=Sam | last=Walker | coauthors= | title=Fantasyland | year=2006 | publisher=Viking | url =http://www.fantasyland.com | work = | pages =54 | accessdate = 2007-07-17 | language = }}</ref> The concept of runners being stranded on base was probably not first conceived of by Shandler. Sabermetrician [[Keith Woolner]] has been researching support-neutral statistics since at least [http://www.baseballprospectus.com/statistics/snwl/snwlart/ 1993], and has often discussed concepts similar to Strand Rate (e.g., Bequeathed Runners inherited/stranded).[http://www.baseballprospectus.com/article.php?articleid=3032] [http://www.baseballprospectus.com/article.php?articleid=2705]
Shandler created [[Tout Wars]] in 1997 after being fed up with the lack of promotion ''[[USA Today]]'' gave its annual [[LABR]] fantasy baseball experts league.<ref>{{cite news | first=Sam | last=Walker | coauthors= | title=Fantasyland | year=2006 | publisher=Viking | url =http://www.fantasyland.com | work = | pages =145 | accessdate = 2007-07-17 }}</ref> He also founded the Annual Fantasy Baseball Symposium at the Arizona Fall League, one of the largest gatherings of fantasy baseball players, now in its 16th year.
Shandler's success as a fantasy player includes the most wins in major fantasy baseball expert leagues.{{Citation needed|date=May 2008}} He won both the NL and AL Tout Wars competitions in 1998 (being the only time anyone has ever won dual championships in the history of national experts competitions), AL Tout Wars in 2000, NL LABR in 2001, and the Fantasy Sports Trade Association League in 2010. He has contributed columns to the sports section of the Huffington Post, ESPN Magazine, ESPN.com, and USA Today. In 2004, he was selected to help form an advisory board for the St. Louis Cardinals, which he served on for approximately two years.
In 2004, Shandler received the Lifetime Achievement Award from the Fantasy Sports Trade Association. In 2012, he was inducted into the Fantasy Sports Writers Association's Hall of Fame.
On April 30, 2013, Shandler announced he would be stepping down from running Baseball HQ, which he had sold to USA Today five years prior. He will continue to write his weekly columns for BaseballHQ.com and USA Today, contribute to the ''Baseball Forecaster'' and will remain active in the fantasy baseball community.
He now runs his own site, RonShandler.com [http://ronshandler.com] where he promotes his latest innovation: the Broad Assessment Balance Sheet (BABS) approach to fantasy baseball team construction.
==See also==
* [[Fantasy baseball]] * [[Fantasy sport]]
